newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Peace pact sparks protests in Philippine city.
newsitem.headline: Peace pact sparks protests in Philippine city.

text.p: Thousands of Christians protested in this southern Philippine city on Tuesday against a government peace pact with Moslem rebels, demanding firearms to back up their opposition.
Shouting "We want arms" and "Guns, guns", about 5,000 people attended a mock funeral symbolising what they regard as the death of democracy in the Philippines.
Bus and pedicab drivers joined in the protest by staging a strike, while banks, shops and schools shut down in sympathy.

Zamboanga city officials say Christians have started forming militia units to oppose the pact which was signed in Manila on Monday. The deal formally ended a 24-year secessionist revolt which killed more than 120,000 people on the main southern island of Mindanao and adjacent islands.
The peace accord involves setting up a rebel-led administrative council to supervise development in 14 southern provinces, to be followed three years later by a plebiscite and regional autonomy.
The country's five million Moslems regard Mindanao as their ancestral homeland, although they are now outnumbered 3-to-1 in the area by Christian settlers.
Christians see the pact as a sell-out to Moslem interests.
